awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Novel prognostic microfluidic systems for cell separation from whole blood
awd_abstract_narration:
Barabino
CBET - 1229954

In the proposed studies microfluidic technologies are uniquely applied in combination with blood separation principles to meet a pressing need for simplified prognostic devices to aid in assessing disease progression and monitoring treatment.  The innovation in this approach is the utilization of dual separation techniques within a single microfluidic system (chip) and using a single whole blood sample to isolate blood cells and circulating endothelial cells.  In blood disorders, such as sickle cell disease, these cells hold important information related to disease pathology.  The separation of multiple cell types from peripheral blood on a single chip represents an advancement in microfluidic technology that has significant potential for reliable assessment of disease prognosis.

Diagnosis and monitoring of disease states is critically important to health.  Engineering tools and systems, such as microfluidics, provide unparalleled opportunities for the development of simple systems that can be used by individuals to assess disease prognosis and monitor treatment.  The proposed studies combine existing microfluidic and separation technologies to separate cellular components from blood and deliver a device with predictive capabilities for a very complex blood disorder.  Separation and analysis of these cellular components, which are linked to disease pathology, are likely to lead to prognostically validated biomarkers and enhance strategies for assessment and treatment.  Minorities are underrepresented in translational research and the proposed project addresses this gap through partnership with the Biomedical Innovation and Translation Scholars (BITS) program led by the PI. BITS is designed to provide education and mentoring to underrepresented minority graduate students and postdocs on innovation, translational research and entrepreneurship.

por.por_cntn:
The project, "Novel Prognostic Microfluidic Systems for Cell Separation from Whole Blood," aimed to uniquely combine existing mechanical and affinity-based microfluidic approaches to design, develop and evaluate a microfluidic system for its prognostic potential based on an analysis of peripheral blood.  We demonstrated that for our purposes, the main factors affecting cell separation in our prototype multiplexed flow devices are: 1) inertial migration of blood cells in capillary flow, 2) effect of cell deformability on inertial migration, 3) margination of cells in bend channels and 4) margination amplification in gradual expansion. The microfluidic channels are geometrically designed to allow specific local control of fluidic resistances to yield different local flow rates and shear stresses.  We designed tested and modeled using complex simulations, a number of different devices exploiting a combination of the factors mentioned above. The most promising prototype devices have been tested with gluteraldehyde fixed red blood cells that approximate the stiffness of sickle red blood cells. The computational models we employed simulated the flow of particulates of varying deformability and stiffness in microchannels and results from the simulations were used to guide refinements of our prototype devices. Currently, the most promising device is being thoroughly characterized and validated using subpopulations of sickle red blood cells and clinical data related to disease progression.  During the course of the project, the PI participated in the NSF National Institute for Mathematical and Biological Synthesis (NIMBioS) workshop entitled, “Modeling Blood Cell Interactions.”  This workshop brought together experimentalists and modelers to share recent progress in the investigation of blood cell interactions and to set future directions for research in this area.  The link between the biomechanics of cells and disease is widely recognized and the stiffness of a cell is a possible indicator the state of a cell in relation to disease, thus following changes in cell stiffness as a disease progresses can be useful in predicting disease prognosis. Investigation and separation of subpopulations of red blood cells differing in stiffness as done in this project has important implications toward a better understanding of the rheology of red blood cells and other cell types and their role in disease. In summary, we were able to demonstrate proof of concept for a novel separation device for subpopulations of blood cells based on cell stiffness. Through integrated experimentation and theoretical modeling, the device was refined and is now being optimized. Once the optimal device is fabricated, it will be evaluated further with sickle red blood cells obtained from individuals living with sickle cell disease over a period of time and comparisons will be made to artificially stiffened cells. These data will be employed to develop a predictive model associating cell stiffness with disease progression. Notably, as the device was being designed, we were able to address fundamental research questions regarding the flow properties of cells.
